page.title: 01Lower Course of Upper Bann
page.content: This block is a low lying area across which the Upper Bann river meanders and finally in the north west corner enters Lough Neagh. There are in the area a few small scattered hills which may rise to 50ft. These are called drumlins and were deposited by ice sheets. On heir slopes pasture predominates, but there are also a few small apple orchards on the well drained slopes with sunny aspects. the intervening depressions are water logged. The resulting rough pasture is used for grazing cattle. The slopes of the drumlins provide dry sites for the farm dwellings and roads. The pattern of settlement is a scattered one with the exception of the single village of Derry Trasna. Patches of scrub woodland including willow trees, occur here and there.
